sense.name: cause a sharp or stinging pain to
sense.examples: Smoke stung his eyes and he blinked away the tears. The peppers stung her mouth and nose. My sunburn stings dreadfully.

sense.name: deliver a sting to, pierce
sense.commentary: Syntax includes: NP1[concrete] STING NP2[concrete] NP1[agent] STING NP2[concrete]
sense.examples: A bee stung my arm yesterday. The poisonous dart stung the deer as it fled through the bushes. Tiny shards of flying glass stung his face.

sense.name: affect the emotional state of
sense.commentary: NOTE: the effect is usually negative, but not always. NOTE: Use this sense for individuals or groups of individuals spoken of as social groups, not for corporations or organizations. Syntax is: NP1[abstract] STING NP2[human]
sense.examples: Consumers are stung by the desire to buy more pizza. His remarks stung her. He was stung by shame.

sense.name: saddle with something unpleasant; affect in a negative way
sense.commentary: Syntax is: NP1[abstract] STING NP2[inanimate] NOTE: In this sense [+animate] also refers to companies, corporations and institutions and other groups populated by a collection of people whose individual emotions are not indexed.
sense.examples: The electronics retailer was stung with a $9 million piracy fine. Stung by the negative ads, the company decided to publish some of their own. The recent scandal stung the new candiate's campaign.
